content.user_title: Fix React async bugs with proven patterns
content.value_statement: Async bugs in React often work in development but fail under load. This skill provides battle-tested patterns for floating promises, race conditions, and async timing issues with Zustand and React Query.

Apply post-condition validation after async operations
Detect hidden async patterns in Zustand actions
Choose between sequential and parallel async execution
Implement proper async patterns in useEffect hooks
Configure ESLint rules for async code quality

prompt_templates.title: Fix floating promise
prompt_templates.prompt: I have an async function that seems to not be waiting properly. The function is called but the code after it runs before completion. Help me identify the floating promise and fix it.

prompt_templates.title: Race condition help
prompt_templates.prompt: My React component has race conditions between state updates. Multiple async operations are interfering with each other. Show me how to properly sequence these operations.

prompt_templates.title: useEffect async
prompt_templates.prompt: I need to fetch data in useEffect but useEffect cannot be async directly. Show me the correct pattern for async data loading with proper cleanup to avoid memory leaks.

prompt_templates.title: Async Zustand pattern
prompt_templates.prompt: I have a Zustand store with async actions. Some work correctly and others have timing issues. Help me identify hidden async patterns and apply the proper async Zustand action pattern.

output_examples.input: I called saveData(item) but my next line that uses the saved data is failing because the data is not there yet.
output: The issue is likely a floating promise. You called saveData without await, so it runs in the background while your next line executes immediately.
Fix: Add await before saveData(item). This ensures the save completes before proceeding.
Prevention: Enable @typescript-eslint/no-floating-promises ESLint rule to catch these at lint time.
For Zustand stores, ensure async actions use the async keyword and properly await internal async calls.

best_practices: Always await async function calls or explicitly mark them as fire-and-forget with a comment
Validate post-conditions after async operations that subsequent code depends on
Use AbortController with fetch calls in useEffect for proper cancellation on unmount
anti_patterns: Calling async functions without await, return, or explicit fire-and-forget comment
Using Promise.all for operations that have dependencies or must run in sequence
Passing async callbacks directly to useEffect without inner async function pattern

faq.question: Does this skill work with React Native?
faq.answer: Yes. All patterns documented work for both React web and React Native. Zustand and React Query are fully compatible with React Native.

faq.question: What async operations does this cover?
faq.answer: The skill covers API calls, database operations, file reads, promise chains, Zustand actions, and any async pattern involving JavaScript promises.

faq.question: Can I use this with other state libraries?
faq.answer: Yes. The patterns for floating promises, race conditions, and useEffect async apply to Redux, Recoil, Jotai, and any React state management library.

faq.question: Does this skill modify my code?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides guidance and examples only. It does not execute code, modify files, or integrate with your development environment.

faq.question: What if my async bug is not covered?
faq.answer: Describe your specific async issue in detail. The skill provides patterns and debugging techniques that can be adapted to many async scenarios beyond the documented examples.

faq.question: How is this different from React Query?
faq.answer: React Query is a library that handles async state management. This skill documents patterns for writing correct async code regardless of whether you use React Query, Zustand, or React state directly.
